thread.title: Pink with a little dot of blue will show men also get breast cancer
thread.title_full: Pink with a little dot of blue will show men also get breast cancer | afr.com

author: Jill Margo
title: Pink with a little dot of blue will show men also get breast cancer
text:
A single blue dot on the pink ribbon would acknowledge men also get breast cancer. by Jill Margo While the pink-washing of breast cancer has successfully raised awareness among women, it has obscured the fact that the disease also exists in men.
There is an emerging view that perhaps a blue dot or a bit of blue somewhere in the pink could remedy this and alert men to the possibility they too can get breast cancer.
"Solid pink reinforces the common perception that males don't get this disease," said breast cancer survivor Rod Ritchie .
"Hence, men's symptoms are not regarded with suspicion, they are not recognised for what they are and, more often, men are diagnosed late."
In addition, he says the lack of male-specific clinical research means treatment for men is not as fine-tuned, being based largely on what is effective for women.
"Consequently, men's survival rates are generally lower," said Mr Ritchie, 64, now web consultant in the Queensland hinterland near Noosa after working as a farmer, a book publisher and a travel writer.
Single blue dot A single dot would represent the one per cent of all breast cancers that occur in men.
 This year about 145 Australian men are expected to be diagnosed with breast cancer and 25 are expected to die from it, says Cancer Australia.
Often there is no obvious cause of their cancer but some may be at added risk through genetic inheritance, hormonal imbalance, lifestyle, occupational factors or exposure to ionising radiation.
"As part of Pinktober, Australia could be the first country to devote one day in the month to male breast cancer while ensuring the pink includes a permanent blue dot," Mr Ritchie said.
In his case, he said the care he received was first-class and equal to that of the many women he was treated alongside.
But when he chatted to them, he was surprised to find several were uncomfortable with pink-washing. Some did not appreciate the politics of pink and the way the breast is sexualised as a marketing tool, with attractive young women used to attract funds when most women develop the cancer in their 60s.
Exploitation concerns Some were concerned about the potential for commercial exploitation of pink and the lack of transparency about the percentage of funds donated and how these were used in research.
Some felt the colour had been hijacked.
On Breast Cancer Network Australia's website, Mr Ritchie recently posted about how it was time for Pinktober, to include the male minority. His post received positive comments.
The idea of a bit of blue is not new. When pink ribbons first appeared en masse in the United States in the 1990s, one woman whose father had died of breast cancer created a pink and blue ribbon to raise awareness that men also got it.
The concept never took hold although now, some organisations abroad, such as The DIPEx Charity in Oxfordshire, were also suggesting it.
The website of the Male Breast Cancer Coalition, a collection of foundations and male survivors sharing their journeys, displays a half-pink, half-blue ribbon.
